sense.name: curiosity or concern about something
sense.examples: I've developed a great interest in that story about the lost turtles. John didn't show much interest in our report. There appears to be some interest in getting this bill passed.

sense.name: having the quality to attract attention
sense.commentary: INTEREST[+quality][+attention_getting] (usually SINGULAR, also w/wo preceding QUANT/DET)
sense.examples: The fresh ginger adds interest to this vegetable dish. The Latin American starlet provides the love interest in that film. Skillful placement of lighting can create areas of interest in a room.

sense.name: for the sake of, or well-being of
sense.examples: It is not in their best interest to drop out of school. They added airbags to cars in the interest of safety. Unfortunately the new policy does not serve the interests of both the city and the state.

sense.name: a rate of return on borrowed or lent money
sense.examples: They are charging 6 percent interest on that loan. How much interest are you currently earning with your savings account? What's the daily interest on the national debt?

sense.name: a diversion, hobby or pleasurable pastime
sense.examples: Sailing and sport diving are among John's interests. We don't seem to have a single interest in common. Mary's passionate interest in cooking has led her to open her own restaurant.

sense.name: rightful portion or stake of something
sense.examples: Sally owns a controlling interest in the company. We each received an interest in the family farm. That financier has oil interests all over the planet.

sense.name: social group with specific aims or purposes
sense.examples: The steel interests have lobbied effectively in Washington. He was criticized for catering to interests other than his constituency.
